The other two conditions represented two different types of lure trials. Another third of these adjectives were related to the originally presented trait word, but ultimately distinct ("Related" targets). For example, a participants completed a false recognition task adapted from prior work (e.g., Todorov & Uleman, 2002;2003). After reading the instructions and completing two practice tasks, participants saw 39 full-color faces randomly paired with behavioral descriptions, each explicitly referencing a specific trait. After a short break, participants moved on to the (b) Test Phase where all 39 faces were presented individually with a single trait word. 13 of these words were initially seen paired with the face in question during the Learning Phase, 13 were related to the originally presented trait, and 13 were unrelated to the originally presented trait. (In this case, "patient" is related to the originally presented trait "easygoing.") Participants indicated whether the trait on screen had appeared in the sentence initially learned about the face during the previous task.

div.head: Face Stimuli
div.p: Faces were taken from the Chicago Face Database (CFD; Ma, Correll, & Wittenbrink, 2015). We made an effort to select relatively average faces (i.e., in terms of attractiveness, trustworthiness, dominance, and unusualness). In order to demonstrate the generalizability of spontaneous trait generalization across target gender appearance, we randomly assigned each participant to see only male-or female-appearing faces. (Thus, target gender is technically manipulated between-subjects, though we did not conduct any formal comparisons based on this factor.) Similarly, the selected faces also varied in race/ethnicity. Specifically, within either gender condition, we selected 10 Asianidentified, 10 Black-identified, 10 Latine-identified, and 10 White-identified faces, for a total of 40 faces. The inclusion of a diversity of racial identities within both the male and female-appearing faces was an attempt to increase the generalizability of this work by better capturing everyday social perception (see Hester & Gray, 2020). These faces were then randomly assigned to sentences in the Learning Phase, meaning that one of the 40 faces was always left out of the set of targets each participant learned about. Examples of the selected stimuli from the CFD can be found in the Appendix.

div.head: Behavioral Stimuli
div.p: Target sentences were created by first adapting a collection behavior-implying sentences (Uleman, 1987) that have been used in previous work in the STI literature (e.g., Todorov & Uleman, 2003). To supplement this set, we also adapted similar sentence stimuli from our own collection (Mende-Siedlecki & Havlicek, in prep), which were previously piloted in terms of trustworthiness, sociability, moral character, and various other social traits. Finally, where necessary, we created new sentence stimuli to fill in any remaining gaps in our set.

When developing these stimuli, we purposefully attempted to select equivalent numbers of positive and negative traits. Moreover, while the same 39 sentences were shown to each participant, we divided these stimuli into three subsets of 13 sentences, which counterbalanced the condition that each subset was ultimately associated with across three versions of the task. For example, the sentence "He was a compassionate listener who reached out to friends when they were going through hard times" was associated with the trait compassionate (Exact condition) in one version, generous (Related condition) in the second version, and smart (unrelated) in the third version. Across these three versions, each trait appeared in each condition once. To ensure that the effect of similarity was not confounded with valence, we endeavored to select Unrelated lures that were still of the same valence as the originally presented traits. To offset the handful of cases where this was not possible, we attempted to include some Related lures that crossed a valence boundary (i.e., dominant-selfish; adventurous-impulsive).
Norming data on the selected traits (collected in a separate pilot study; N = 97)
suggested that overall, Related traits were much more similar to the originally presented

div.head: Analyses
div.p: While we originally operationalized similarity in a categorical fashion (i.e., Related versus Unrelated lures), a previous pilot investigation demonstrated considerable variability in participants' perceptions of similarity, both between participants and between individual traits. As such, our preregistered primary analysis collapses across the Related and Unrelated conditions to capitalize on this variability and operationalizes similarity continuously rather than categorically.

We analyzed participants' responses to the false recognition task using generalized mixed effects logistic regression. We used the participants' responses to the false recognition task ("Yes" responses [indicating that the participant mistakenly thought the lure in question had appeared in the Learning Phase] were coded as 1, "No" responses were coded as a 0) as our DV. Perceived similarity between the originally presented trait and the lure trait (collected from each participant after the Test Phase; rated on a 1-to-7 scale from very dissimilar to very similar) as a predictor of choice.

For the primary analysis, the similarity predictor was calculated across participants (consensus perceived similarity) and mean-centered. Our pre-registration stated that a random intercept and random slope would be included, and if the model did not converge, then we would iteratively remove the smallest random effect until it converged. Similarly, we conducted another preregistered analysis with idiosyncratic (i.e., subject-level) judgments of perceived trait similarity as the predictor, rather than the consensus values used in the primary analysis.

In our preregistration, we indicated that a somewhat simpler test of the same hypothesis would be to simply examine whether participants gave more "Yes" responses to Related lures versus Unrelated lures, independent of similarity judgments. To conduct this test, we conducted a one-way ANOVA on the proportion of "Yes" responses across the Exact, Related, and Unrelated conditions. (In addition to the prediction regarding Related versus Unrelated lures, we also expected that participants would give more "Yes" responses in the Exact condition as compared to Related and Unrelated trials.

div.head: Exploratory Measures
div.p: We also collected data on a variety of individual difference variables (i.e., region of the US identified with, the Big Five, self-construal scale, perceived social status, morning vs. night preference, religiosity, etc.). We plan to use these measures for exploratory analyses that will guide future work on group differences in trait maps.

div.head: Assessing Similarity as a Continuous Predictor
div.p: We predicted that perceived trait similarity would be positively associated with "Yes" responses in the Test Phase. Our results were consistent with this hypothesis; we found a statistically significant and positive relationship between consensus judgments of trait similarity and participants' responses in the Test Phase (b = 0.08, 95% CI [0.007, 0.15], z = 2.15, SE = 0.04, p = 0.032; Table 3A). A similar relationship was also observed when using idiosyncratic similarity ratings as the primary predictor (b = 0.05, 95% CI [0.005, 0.09], z = 2.10, SE = 0.02, p = 0.035; Table 3B). In both cases, participants were more likely to falsely remember traits as having been explicitly referred to in the Learning Phase when trait similarity (both consensus and idiosyncratic) between the lure and target trait was greater. Interestingly, when consensus and participant-specific judgments were pit against each other in the same model, neither consensus nor participant-specific similarity ratings were significantly associated with "Yes" responses (i.e., false recognition reflecting trait generalization) in the Test Phase (both ps > .276; Table 3B).

div.head: Assessing the Effect of Similarity Categorically
div.p: As described above, an alternative approach would have been to collapse across these individual differences in perceived similarity and simply compare the proportion of 'Yes' responses as a function of whether participants were evaluating an Exact, Related, or Unrelated trait. Indeed, a one-way ANOVA revealed a positive, significant main effect of trait condition(F(2,232) = 49.24, p < .001, p 2 = .30; Figure 5) In the false recognition paradigm, participants were most likely to correctly recall "exact" traits as having appeared during the Learning Phase, but critically, were also more likely to incorrectly recall related (vs. unrelated) traits as having appeared.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: While Experiments 1 and 2 provide evidence for the robustness and socialspecificity of similarity-based trait generalization, they left open the question of when this generalization occurs. Building on this work, Experiment 3 demonstrated that trait generalization can occur spontaneously at encoding. Specifically, participants completing a false recognition paradigm were more likely to show false memory for traits to the extent that they were more conceptually similar to the originally learned target traits. We take this as evidence that upon encoding, participants' initial impressions regarding a particular trait can spread and activate other related trait concepts. Moreover, we found evidence of generalization when operationalizing similarity through both consensus and idiosyncratic (i.e., participant-level) judgments. In addition, our use of a wide variety of traits and behavioral contexts in Experiment 3 offers further evidence for the generalizability of the trait generalization phenomenon demonstrated in Experiments 1 and 2.

div.head: GENERAL DISCUSSION
div.p: Research on person perception frequently argues that our social impressions of other people should allow us to predict their future behavioreven in new situations that differ from those in which those impressions were originally formed (Hackel et al., 2022;Son et al., 2021). Here, we explored how people generalize initial impressions by using conceptual maps of social knowledge that allow them to make flexible predictions about others' behavior across various novel contexts. Across three experiments, we find evidence that perceived similarity between traits (both on a consensus and idiosyncratic level) guides such generalization.

Experiment 1 provides initial evidence for this phenomenon. Here, we observed that the conceptual similarity between the traits associated with different social game contexts guided decision-making from one context to the next. Specifically, to the extent that participants valued traits like friendliness or generosity, they were more likely to choose a sociable partner in novel contexts (i.e., a Photo Game revealing friendliness, a Giveaway Game revealing generosity, etc.) to the extent that those contexts required similar traits to the initial learning context. Critically, this effect was observed when participants thought they were making social choices about other humans, but not when they were playing with non-human slot machines, suggesting that trait-based generalization occurs in social, but not non-social, contexts. This indicates that trait knowledge is particularly useful and prevalent in guiding social interactions, where behavioral instances would presumably be more likely to reflect a latent dispositional structure characterizing one's personality (Gershman, Norman, & Niv, 2015).

Experiment 2 extends these findings by illustrating this generalization phenomenon across a wider set of traits and contexts-and notably, when learning is reduced to associating a single trait word with a given social target. In other words, here we demonstrate the generalizability of trait-based generalization, confirming that its relevance is not constrained to the particular traits and social scenarios deployed in Experiment 1.

We further corroborated that generalization is not merely a function of commonalities in valence across traits: conceptual similarity between traits continued to predict choice even when valence was accounted for in our model, distinguishing this phenomenon from typical conceptualizations of the halo effect (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977). Additionally, we found that both consensus and idiosyncratic (i.e., participant-specific) similarity ratings predict partner choice in the social games. This suggests that individual differences in conceptual maps play a significant role in individual decision-making.

Finally, we turned our attention to the spontaneity of this generalization phenomenon in Experiment 3. Prior work illustrates that traits are spontaneously and effortlessly inferred from behavior, supporting the formation of lasting social impressions (e.g., Todorov & Uleman, 2002;2003). Here we tested whether a similar process supports generalization. Using a false recognition task, Experiment 3 provides evidence that indeed, trait generalization occurs spontaneously at encoding. Specifically, we found evidence that perceived similarity predicted participants' false memories for traits in a recall task: they were more likely to say that a lure trait was used to describe a particular face to the extent that it was seen as more similar to the originally presented trait.

div.head: Connections to Prior Work
div.p: Beyond the overarching dimensions that our social impressions can be plotted along (e.g., Abele & Wojciszke, 2007;Fiske, Cuddy, & Glick, 2007;Oosterhof & Todorov, 2008), more recent data suggests that conceptual relationships between trait concepts provide a critical scaffolding for social cognition and perception (e.g., Stolier et al., 2020;Oh, Martin, & Freeman, 2022). Using this framework as a foundation, the present work sought to test how those conceptual linkages might facilitate our ability to flexibly predict behavior based on socially interactions that were limited to a particular context. In so doing, we directly expanded on several programs of contemporary research.

For example, Frolichs and colleagues (2022) recently demonstrated evidence of trait generalization based on self-reported traits; perceivers anticipated that individuals who described themselves as possessing a given trait would also possess related traits too, as a function of real-world co-occurrences between those traits. Here, we conceptually replicate this phenomenon, but critically, extend it to traits that have been gleaned directly through instrumental learning, advancing our knowledge of when and how trait generalization occurs. Across this work, similarity-based trait generalization facilitated social decisionmaking across a diversity of novel contexts expanding on prior work that provided more constrained tests of generalization (e.g., the same motive across different contexts [van Baar et al. 2021] or different expressions of the same core trait [math versus verbal competence in Hackel et al., 2022]). Further, our results also dovetail with recent data suggesting that network similarity between traits serves as a guiding mechanism for self-referential judgments (Elder et al. 2023). Finally, this work (particularly Experiment 1)

provides important evidence demonstrating that trait generalization is a socially specific process, adding to a growing body of literature aiming to characterize domain-specific versus domain-general mechanisms supporting dynamic social cognition (e.g., Hackel, Mende-Siedlecki, & Amodio, 2020).

div.head: Limitations and Future Directions
div.p: While this work provides important insights into our ability to flexibly generalize existing trait impressions, some limitations are worth consideration. When constructing these studies, we aimed to be programmatic; each study attempted to address flaws or fill gaps left by the previous. For example, Experiment 1 was limited by a small range of domains and traits and a focus on a consensus-based operationalization of perceived similarity. Moreover, our design was such that it was possible that the Learning Game afforded inferences about other traits beyond sociability. While these issues directly influenced our design and goals for Experiment 2, they are still important to point out.
Similarly, both Experiments 1 and 2 represented targets with images (i.e., fractals in Exp.

1, AI-generated art in Exp. 2) to avoid biases and stereotypes associated with specific racial and gender identities. Consequently, these studies have clear limitations in terms of ecological validity. By limiting the inferences that participants could draw about these targets to their in-game behavior (Exp. 1) or personality test results (Exp. 2), these stimuli are devoid of the social cognitive richness that people actually encounter in daily life.
While we addressed this to some extent in Experiment 3, we encourage future work to continue to push the boundaries of ecological validity, through even more diverse sets of stimuli.

By the same token, we would also welcome tests of trait generalization that employ more realistic, direct social interactions. In Experiments 1 and 2, participants' social decision-making amounted to selecting which targets to "hire" based on their instrumentally (Exp. 1) or passively learned (Exp. 2) trait dispositions. Secondly, these games likely do not perfectly replicate social decisions and interactions in the real world; most people don't hire someone to play Rock-Paper-Scissors for them on a daily basis, however we applaud anyone who does. How, then, does trait generalization unfold (or perhaps differ) in more direct social interactions between two individuals? Future research could operationalize learning in terms of more naturalistic stimuli (Jolly et al., 2023) or structured interactions (e.g., Ames & Fiske, 2013) to create more authentic contexts for learning and generalization, or even behavioral vignettes or resumes that more closely approximate real-world instances of these phenomena. Consequently, despite our efforts in Experiments 2 and 3, there is still an ocean of more traits and social contexts that could be included in future follow-up work.

Another limitation concerns our test of "spontaneous" trait generalization in Experiment 3. It could be argued that our false recognition paradigm (adapted from work on spontaneous trait inference [Todorov & Uleman, 2002]) does not provide a conservative test of the automaticity of generalization; while we have demonstrated that generalization is occurring at without prompting or planning, the present work was not designed to assess the efficiency of this process at encoding. Other work provides useful suggestions for study designs that could be used to extend our understanding of the social cognitive processes involved in trait generalization. For example, across three follow-up experiments, Todorov and Uleman (2003) manipulated time pressure, depth of processing, and cognitive load, reasoning that if similar patterns were observed when participants' attentional resources were taxed or diverted, this would provide stronger evidence for the efficiency of spontaneous trait inference. The same logic could be applied here. For example, one might manipulate whether participants are under cognitive load during the Learning Phase of the task. If similar differences between "Yes" responses to related and unrelated traits were observed even under load, this would suggest that generalization depends, at least in part, on relatively automatic processing of trait informationand not solely on controlled processes.

Further, though we did use both male-and female-appearing stimuli with varying racial identities in Experiment 3, as of yet, this work has not looked into how trait generalization and conceptual maps might differ as a function of target identity. Groupbased stereotypes regarding gender, race, class, age, or ideology might all provide important influences on the affordances from one trait to another. For example, how might the links between assertive and competent vary when considering a man versus a woman, or between dominant and untrustworthy when considering a Black person versus a White person? In turn, how are these conceptual maps trained up on the perceiver side of things through experience and socialization? One might imagine that liberals and conservatives, city-dwellers and rural-dwellers, and religious and nonreligious people might learn to ascribe different meanings to trait words like patriotic, nosy, or pious, with consequences for the paths that wind through their conceptual maps of trait space, and in turn, generalization itself. As such, future work should devote time to investigating both target and perceiver identity as key moderators of this phenomenon.

Finally, there is room for future work to consider a broader spectrum of "nonsocial" targets. Our primary manipulation in Experiment 1 revolved around defining the targets as previous participants or computerized slot machines. While our results suggested that similarity-based trait generalization only occurred for human targets (and not the slots), contemporary increases in AI prevalence, usage, and capability hint at intriguing questions regarding how perceivers might treat a more advanced non-human agent. If an AI-based target were perceived to fall somewhere in the middle between human and non-human, it would be interesting to test the extent to which inferences about its dispositions might be generalized to novel contexts.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Humans form impressions of others by inferring stable traits from instances of social behavior, allowing us to predict how others will likely behave in the future. These predictions, in turn, shape our social decision-making and attitudes towards others. Our findings suggest that this ability is flexibly achieved through trait generalization, which itself is guided by conceptual maps of trait-based similarity. Moreover, we provide evidence that trait generalization is socially specific, cannot be solely explained by valence, and can occur spontaneously during the encoding process. Taken together, this work illuminates a core mechanism that helps humans navigate complex social environments through a social cognitive lens.

Critically, as hypothesized, we found a Trait Similarity x Condition interaction, b = .76, SE = .13, z = 5.87, p < .001 indicating that the effect of Trait Similarity depended on Condition (Figure 2). Specifically, simple effects analysis revealed that Trait Similarity strongly predicted choices in the social condition, b = 1.49, SE = .20, z = 7.63, p < .001, but did not predict choices at all in the non-social condition, b = -.03, SE = .17, z = -.20, p = .84. Within the human condition, participants preferred the sociable target when Trait Similarity was high (1 SD above the mean), b = .89, SE = .17, z = 5.37, p < .001, but avoided the sociable target when Trait Similarity was low (1 SD below the mean), b = -.36, SE = .16, z = -2.26, p = .02. These findings indicate that participants generalized value in new contexts based on trait inferences specifically in social, but not non-social, interactions. Discussion Experiment 1 demonstrated evidence of trait-based generalization to novel social domains. This finding directly expands on our prior work showing that people generalize context-specific impressions of competence to make flexible decisions in social dilemmas.

A final third of these adjectives were unrelated to the originally presented trait word ("Unrelated" targets). For example, an Unrelated target described as funny in the Learning Phase might be paired with patient in the Test Phase. Related or unrelated trait adjectives were categorized on the basis of trait similarity, determined in a separate pilot study (N = 97).For each target appearing during the Test Phase, participants were asked if the adjective presented on screen had appeared in the sentence that participants initially learned about the face in question during the Learning Phase. Participants provided a binary Yes/No response. Prior to beginning the Test Phase, participants again read thorough instructions, which contained two sample trials referring back to the sample targets encountered in the Learning Phase instructions..

This difference was maintained in each of the three subsets of sentences we arrived at (Related Ms ranged from 5.08 to 5.18; Unrelated Ms ranged from 3.92 to 3.95; all ps < .001). This expected difference was conserved in the present sample, where participants rated Related traits as much more similar (M = 5.06, SD = 0.85) to the originally presented target traits, related to Unrelated traits (M = 3.37, SD = 0.91; t(116) = 25.23, p < .001, d = 2.33).

Unsurprisingly, the highest percentage of 'Yes' responses was observed in the Exact condition (M = .590, SD = .163). Dovetailing with the multilevel model results above, participants also gave more 'Yes' responses for Related traits (M = .443, SD = .150) than for Unrelated traits (M = .406, SD = .163). This difference between Related and the Unrelated conditions was statistically significant (t(116) = 2.17, p = .032, d = .200).

body.note: instance,Frolichs and colleagues (2022) illustrated how people generalize impressions based on self-reported traits, but did not examine generalization in the context of observationally or instrumentally learned traits, which are likely more reflective of realworld social learning. Further, it will be crucial to test how this generalization process supports and informs subsequent social decision-making. Related, while van Baar colleagues (2021) demonstrate how inferences about social motives can be generalizedeven when they're associated with different patterns of behavior-across different contexts, this work was placed less emphasis on the generalization of this learning to related goals, nor did it explicitly test perceived similarity as a guiding mechanism. To this point, Elder and colleagues (2023) did show how network similarity between traits shaped evaluations, but this work focused on self-referential judgments, rather than the judgment of others.Moreover, while Hackel and colleagues (2022) laid the groundwork by providing evidence for generalization on a relatively proximal level (how competence in one context [e.g., math] generalized to another [e.g., science]), it is critical to test this generalization process across more distal and distinct trait concepts and social contexts. Finally, as discussed previously, there is an extensive literature illustrating similarity-based generalization in non-social contexts. At the same time, recent work illustrates that social cognitive mechanisms may meaningfully distinguish between social and non-social learning. For example, in a task where participants learned about targets varying orthogonally in trait generosity and reward value, they prioritized learning about generosity information when these targets were described as other humans (i.e., a social context), but prioritized reward when the targets were described as non-social slot machines. Thus, it will be critical to test the social specificity of trait generalization. Taken together, the studies collected in this manuscript will directly address these gaps in knowledge.

div.head: .. D EXAMPLE OF EXPERIMENT 3 CHICAGO FACE DATABASE IMAGES81
div.p: Chapter 5

div.head: EXPERIMENT 3: CAN SIMILARITY-BASED TRAIT GENERALIZATION OCCUR SPONTANEOUSLY AT ENCODING
div.p: While Experiments 1 and 2 demonstrate how similarity-based maps of social knowledge support trait generalization, they leave unanswered the question of when such generalization occursduring the initial encoding of a trait impression, or later, when that impression is retrieved prior to decision making? To test this, we used a classic false recognition paradigm adapted from the spontaneous trait inference literature, which has previously provided evidence that we spontaneously infer traits implied by behavior during encoding (Todorov & Uleman, 2002).

Participants in Experiment 3 viewed sentences explicitly describing behavior in trait terms, each randomly paired with a face. Later, participants viewed the same faces along with a single trait word and asked if that trait was previously used to describe the individual in question. We hypothesized that trait similarity would be predictive of falsely remembering traits, such that the greater the similarity between the target and lure trait, the more likely a participant would falsely remember that trait. Thus, this would support the process that generalization occurs spontaneously at encoding. Table 3. Similarity shapes the spontaneous generalization of trait knowledge. Both consensus (3A) and participant-specific judgments (3B) of similarity between lures and original trait adjectives were positively and significantly associated with "Yes" responses (i.e., false recognition) in the spontaneous trait generalization paradigm. That said, when pit against each other, neither predictor remained significant (3C).
